The Office of Human Resources is sponsoring a lunchtime fitness class for faculty and staff. YogaBlend will be offered Thursdays at 12:35 p.m. beginning June 15 in the Antone Academic Center, Room 126.

Certified yoga instructor Nancy Escher will lead this energizing 45-minute class that combines yoga, core exercises and strength training with hand-held weights. Improve flexibility, balance and strength while giving attention to breath and mindfulness.

Yoga mats and weights are available, if needed. The cost is $50 for eight classes, $35 for five classes or $8 to drop in.

For more information, or to register, contact Escher at (401) 341-2157 or nancy.escher@salve.edu.

Members of the Class of 2021 are invited to apply for this year’s Service Plunge, which provides a select group of new students with a challenging and fun opportunity to lead and learn through active experiences.

Through direct and indirect service, “plungees” learn the importance of service, social justice and civic engagement. They also meet community needs, identify and build upon community assets and share their experiences with the campus community.

This year’s Service Plunge will be held Aug. 30 to Sept. 3. Applications are available online and should be submitted by noon Friday, June 30.

Participants will work with the following community partners:

Child & Family, the largest and most comprehensive social service provider in Newport County. Volunteers will assist in the Sandpipers Early Learning Center, an early care and education program.

God’s Community Garden, which grows thousands of pounds of fresh vegetables and herbs for local soup kitchens, senior centers, shelters and food pantries. Volunteers will dig, pick and care for the plants and work the farm stand.

Rhode Island Food Bank, which distributes food to people in need through a statewide network of 160 member agencies, including food pantries, meal sites, shelters, youth programs and senior centers.

Norman Bird Sanctuary, a 325-acre bird sanctuary, nature preserve and museum. The sanctuary preserves and protects its habitats and resources for the benefit of birds and wildlife, and for people’s education and enjoyment.

Gifts to Give, through which kids donate their gently-used clothes, toys and books and then volunteer to process, organize and package the donations, transforming them into individual gift packages.

For more information on this year’s Service Plunge, contact the Office of Community Service at (401) 341-2440 or community.services@salve.edu.

Glenn Clark has been named associate vice president for information technology/chief information officer at Salve Regina. His appointment officially begins July 1.

“Salve Regina continues to be a unique and exceptional environment where we can all help contribute to overcoming the challenges and change ahead,” Clark said. “The opportunity to lead such a great team of people who have both the experience and drive to take on these challenges and changes is something I am really looking forward to.”

Clark has been with the University since 2006 and has served as acting associate vice president for information technology/chief information officer since September 2016.

“Glenn has been a key contributor in developing the University’s network architecture, functionality and security,” said Bill Hall, vice president for administration/chief financial officer. “His contributions have led to a number of improvements in our technology services and successful implementation of numerous projects and initiatives for the campus. Glenn has also helped to forge relationships with a variety of high-level technology manufacturers and providers such as Cisco, HP, Microsoft, Apple, Cox Communication, Atrion and OSHEAN, all who have become trusted partners and contributors to the University.”

Clark holds a bachelor’s degree in business administration and management from Providence College and an MBA from Bryant University. He also holds certifications in Cisco, Microsoft, IT security and project management. For the past 15 years, Clark has served as an adjunct professor at Bryant, Salve Regina and the Community College of Rhode Island.

The Gordon Research Conferences, which provide an international forum for the presentation and discussion of frontier research in the biological, chemical and physical sciences and their related technologies, will be held at Salve Regina throughout the summer.

During the conferences, scientists with common professional interests come together for intense discussions and examination of the most advanced aspects of their field. To encourage open communication, participants agree that any information presented during the conference is not for public use, and guests are not permitted to attend lectures and discussion sessions.

Conferences taking place at Salve Regina this summer include:

Neurotrophic Factors – June 4-9

Gordon Research Seminar: Atomic Physics – June 10-11

Atomic Physics – June 11-16

Heterocyclic Compounds – June 18-23

Gordon Research Seminar: Nucleosides, Nucleotides and Oligonucleotides – June 24-25

Nucleosides, Nucleotides and Oligonucleotides – June 25-30

Gordon Research Seminar: Organometallic Chemistry – July 8-9

Organometallic Chemistry – July 9-14

Gordon Research Seminar: Red Cells – July 15-16

Red Cells – July 16-21

Gordon Research Seminar: Microbial Adhesion and Signal Transduction – July 22-23

Microbial Adhesion and Signal Transduction – July 23-28

Gordon Research Seminar: Dynamics at Surfaces – July 29-30

Dynamics at Surfaces – July 30 to Aug. 4

Gordon Research Seminar: Angiogenesis – Aug. 5-6

Angiogenesis – Aug. 6-11

In association with upcoming marketing initiatives, Salve Regina is seeking input from current students and recent University graduates.

Representatives from Dartlet will be running several interactive workshops Wednesday, June 7 in Ochre Court. These workshops are designed to assess the demographic, psychographic, socioeconomic and lifestyle preferences of current Salve Regina students and recent graduates. Results from each workshop will be used to help identify the type of student most likely to be interested in attending Salve Regina, and how to best reach them.

Workshops are one hour in length and snacks will be provided. Sessions are scheduled for 9 a.m., 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. Wednesday

To register for a workshop, visit salve.edu/dartlet-project.

Pitcher Patrick Maybach ’20 was recently named New England rookie of the year by D3baseball.com. He was also a first team all-New England selection by both the American Baseball Coaches Association and D3baseball.com.

Several other Seahawks were also recognized, including catcher Christian Vargas ’18, pitcher Jimmy Fitzgerald ’18 and infielder John Militano ’18.

Maybach finished the regular season with a 1.36 ERA and went 9-0 with one save in 10 appearances. Both his ERA and win total were the best in the conference at the end of conference play. Maybach also struck out 67 batters, ranking him third in the conference, and ranked eighth nationally in ERA. He was named national pitcher of the week by the National Collegiate Baseball Writers’ Association for the week ending March 12.

Vargas was named second team all-New England by the American Baseball Coaches Association and D3baseball.com. He had a strong season at the plate, finishing in the top 10 in the conference in batting average (seventh), on-base percentage (sixth) and slugging percentage (eighth). Vargas was also a major run producer, scoring 29 runs, driving in 28 and hitting three home runs. He was second in the conference in runners caught stealing with 18.

Fitzgerald was named second team all-New England by the American Baseball Coaches Association. He was one of the best strikeout pitchers in Division III, averaging 12.55 strikeouts per nine innings, ranking him first in the conference and 10th nationally. Fitzgerald went 6-1 this year with a 2.75 ERA while holding opponents to a .173 average. He had 73 strikeouts and one shutout this season.

Militano was named third team all-New England by the American Baseball Coaches Association. He was the league leader in hits (44) and stolen bases (29). Militano crossed the plate 39 times to finish second in the conference, and his .358 batting average placed him sixth in the conference.
